SCCommittee Review- PartII
By Andrew Hurley
Education-Melissa Manlove
Because Manlove has taken a leave of absence this semester, her position as chairperson of
the SC Education committee is currently vacant. SC president Michael Steele plans to announce
a replacement next week.
During the fall semester the committee very rarely met as a whole. Manlove divided the
committee's work into three subcommittees: advising, intersession, and foreign language requirement. Manlove explained that the committee was also working on an education survey of Hopkins undergraduates.
Steele expressed disappointment with the committee's performance, noting that it failed to
submit its required mid-year report. He added that many contmittee members had complained
to him about the infrequency of meetings and several members were unaware of their chairperson's identity. "As far as 1 know," said Steele, "they have accomplished nothing."

FinancialAid--Larry Wolfe
Due to the reshuffling of the Financial Aid Office, the Financial Aid Committee has been
unable to du much work. A good deal of the first semester has been spent organizing and getting
familiar with the Financial Aid Office. The committee, which met weekly, also made plans for
the possible publication of a newsletter and the distribution of a pamphlet that would notify
students of the many changes that have occurred concerning Financial Aid.

LegalRights--Amir Halevy
Since the beginning of last summer, Chairman Halevy and his committee, composed of
seventeen members, have been working on the Judicial Code. Committee meetings were held
every week, with the group and the administration constantly discussing the document. In addition to drafting the code, the committee worked to win its approval by the Student Council. The
committee, which will continue to meet weekly, also expects to distribute information about
student-tenant relationships.

Housing--PaulRosen
During the fall semester, the Housing Committee has worked on the publication of a book
that will give advice on how to live in Baltimore. Although the committee met only once every
other month, Rosen has been in constant contact with the ten committee members.
The committee has encountered several problems. For example, last year's committee
decided to write the book using a computer, which resulted in many of this year's committee
members being unfamiliar with the computer language that was chosen, forcing them to spend a
great deal of time learning it. Another problem is the task of raising funds for the book's publication; however, SC president Michael Steele is confident that the funds will be available.

StudentServices--John Kelleher
According to SC president Steele, Student Services, the one committee that causes the
most concern among students and puts the most pressure on the chairman, has done nothing so far
this year. Committee chairman Kelleher, who recently resigned from this position, explained that
he had problems organizing the committee and delegating authority. Kelleher's committee of ten
expected to participate in solicitation of bids for a new book store and the establishment of a
peer counseling program. However, these issues were dealt with by Kelleher alone. The newly
appointed chairman of the committee is freshman Colin Flynn.

existing plants.

SCCommittee Review- PartII
By Andrew Hurley
Education-Melissa Manlove
Because Manlove has taken a leave of absence this semester, her position as chairperson of
the SC Education committee is currently vacant. SC president Michael Steele plans to announce
a replacement next week.
During the fall semester the committee very rarely met as a whole. Manlove divided the
committee's work into three subcommittees: advising, intersession, and foreign language requirement. Manlove explained that the committee was also working on an education survey of Hopkins undergraduates.
Steele expressed disappointment with the committee's performance, noting that it failed to
submit its required mid-year report. He added that many contmittee members had complained
to him about the infrequency of meetings and several members were unaware of their chairperson's identity. "As far as 1 know," said Steele, "they have accomplished nothing."

FinancialAid--Larry Wolfe
Due to the reshuffling of the Financial Aid Office, the Financial Aid Committee has been
unable to du much work. A good deal of the first semester has been spent organizing and getting
familiar with the Financial Aid Office. The committee, which met weekly, also made plans for
the possible publication of a newsletter and the distribution of a pamphlet that would notify
students of the many changes that have occurred concerning Financial Aid.

LegalRights--Amir Halevy
Since the beginning of last summer, Chairman Halevy and his committee, composed of
seventeen members, have been working on the Judicial Code. Committee meetings were held
every week, with the group and the administration constantly discussing the document. In addition to drafting the code, the committee worked to win its approval by the Student Council. The
committee, which will continue to meet weekly, also expects to distribute information about
student-tenant relationships.

Housing--PaulRosen
During the fall semester, the Housing Committee has worked on the publication of a book
that will give advice on how to live in Baltimore. Although the committee met only once every
other month, Rosen has been in constant contact with the ten committee members.
The committee has encountered several problems. For example, last year's committee
decided to write the book using a computer, which resulted in many of this year's committee
members being unfamiliar with the computer language that was chosen, forcing them to spend a
great deal of time learning it. Another problem is the task of raising funds for the book's publication; however, SC president Michael Steele is confident that the funds will be available.

StudentServices--John Kelleher
According to SC president Steele, Student Services, the one committee that causes the
most concern among students and puts the most pressure on the chairman, has done nothing so far
this year. Committee chairman Kelleher, who recently resigned from this position, explained that
he had problems organizing the committee and delegating authority. Kelleher's committee of ten
expected to participate in solicitation of bids for a new book store and the establishment of a
peer counseling program. However, these issues were dealt with by Kelleher alone. The newly
appointed chairman of the committee is freshman Colin Flynn.

BY WALTER HOOK
"Boatman! Boatman!" cries a
weary, cloaked wayfarer, holding high his
lantern in the fog. A ragged rustic, oar in
hand, slips carefully into the shadows,
avoiding the traveler's searching eyes.
The man is Sir Thomas More, and being
seen with him is considered an insult to
the King, Henry VIII. The play is A Man
For All Seasons (Center Stage, now
through March 8).
Lady Margaret, (Sir Thomas
More's daughter) curtseys before the
King. "Blow!" he commands, withdrawing a pipe from his robes. She
blows, signalling the minstrels to begin a
song. Then the business begins. The
King begs Sir Thomas More, noted
intellectual and Chancellor of England, to
reconsider. The King's wife is barren, and
he wants a divorce, but the laws of the
Catholic Church and the State forbid it.
The Pope has been ignored, the Catholic
Church replaced by the Church of England, and the Parliament has voted the
divorce legal, all to give King Henry
an heir. But More has refused to either
condone or condemn the divorce, and his
silence is far louder than the pleas of
Parliament.
Secretary Cromwell sips mead in a
candle-lit tavern, devising with his cronies
legal threats which could intimidate Sir
Thomas into supporting the marriage.
Later, echoes in a stone tower whisper,
"Treason."
More, who believes that no man is
above the law, yet refuses to betray the

King either, decides to abstain from
commenting on the divorce. He resigns
his post as Chancellor in the hope of
vanishing from the public eye, but this
act merely makes him more famous. The
King's reputation is being tainted by
More's actions, so pressure from Henry
steadily grows stronger. More declares
again and again that the law must be the ,
causeway by which any citizen can walk
safely through life, and thus, as he is in
no way bound by the law to condone the
King's divorce, he has no need to fear.

When the King demands that More
support his divorce, and More .refuses,
there are accusations of treason. More
proclaims that when a man's actions are
forcibly separated from the dictates of his
conscience by the law itself, society has
come to advocate lying and trickery and
punish honesty. More's conscience is
apparently established by "God's law,"
and therefore human law should, in
More's mind, reflect divine will.

As a contrast to More, the narrator, called "The Common Man," makes
the most of his position as Sir Thomas'
servant. He accepts countless shillings for
information, without a guilty conscience.
The Common Man, in fact, has no conscience. His actions are those which bring
him the most money, or which keep him
out of trouble. He rides the currents of
history, while More fights them.
